@article{10.1145/226643.226644,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable formallowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

matrix.description: The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $d$-$DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $d$-$DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $d$-$DNNF$ clause.

d-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.
PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $DNNF$ clause.

PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PIFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Wegener_1987,Darwiche_2002}.
IPDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
MODSDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

nFBDDDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $CNF$ is a subset of $NNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

nOBDDDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFnOBDD in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
It is well-known that some $CNF$ formulas (i.e. $\neg PARITY_n=\neg\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicants.

SDNNFDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFSDNNF in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.

uFBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFuFBDD in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

uOBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFuOBDD in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFdec-DNNF in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFdec-SDNNF in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, d-DNNF is a subset of DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

$d$-$DNNF$s can polynomially represent the disjunction of two functions with conflicting variable orders, which forces $FBDD$s to grow exponentially to track the state of both orders within a single "read-once" path.
IPDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $d-DNNF$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.
d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to NNF.

nOBDDnFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFnOBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2000}.
PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFCNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
Proposition 3.5 shows that quasi-polynomial compilation exists. Proposition 3.10 shows that this cannot be made polynomial-time.
uFBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFuOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then uFBDDuOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts uFBDDuOBDD being no-quasi.

OBDDFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2000}.
Shown by Corollary 3.5 of \citet{Beame_2013}.

dec-SDNNFdec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFdec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFdec-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFdec-DNNF being no-quasi \citet{Beame_2013}.

OBDD$_<$d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $d$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $d$-$DNNF$, so transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to DNNF.

dec-SDNNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. FBDDnFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

IPDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-SDNNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-SDNNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

MODSCNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-SDNNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-SDNNFCNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to nFBDD.

uOBDDd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then uOBDDOBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts uOBDDOBDD$_<$ being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

Unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses.

Explanation: Suppose not; then $\forall\Lambda\in DNF$, $\exists$ an equivalent $\Lambda_*\in d$-$DNNF$ of polynomial size. Then we may perform a clausal entailment check on some $CNF$ sentence $\Sigma \in CNF$ with respect to some clause $\gamma$ by checking whether $(\neg\Sigma\vee\gamma)\in DNF$ is valid. But we may perform a validity check on $(\neg\Sigma\vee\gamma)_* \in d$-$DNNF$ in polynomial time. Since we can now perform a polynomial-time clausal entailment check on all $CNF$ sentences, the polynomial hierarchy collapses.

Recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the (not necessarily disjoint) rewirings of the nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and a 1-edge. We note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$ gates are decomposable. Furthermore, $\vee$ gates are only introduced in the rewriting, so we obtain a $dec$-$DNNF$ in linear time.

Consider the $DNF$ formula $\Pi_n= igvee_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicants form and each clause in $\Pi_n$ is an essential prime implicant of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Pi_n\in IP$.

Since the early work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicates of a formula is a lower bound on the number of clauses that can be found in any $CNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, $
eg\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, so any $CNF$ representation of $
eg\Pi_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $IP$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to DNNF.

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}	o\{0,1\}$ so $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=0 \iff I 	ext{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. This is the negation of the clique detection function. However, it can be shown that $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicates, which implies that not every $IP$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.

Consider the Boolean functions $\psi_n,\phi_n:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ that respectively test whether, in an $n \times n$ Boolean matrix, either the number of 1's is odd and there is a full row of 1's, or the number of 1's is even and there is a column full of 1's. An $FBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ may simulate either $\psi_n$ or $\phi_n$, and thus the $uFBDD$ $\psi_n\vee\phi_n$ is of size $O(n^2)$; however, an $FBDD$ for $\psi_n\vee\phi_n$ is provably of size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$.

As defined by Darwiche 2002, $PI$ is a subset of $CNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is listed as an open problem in A Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).

Consider the $CNF$ formula $\Sigma_n= igwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicates form and each clause in $\Sigma_n$ is an essential prime implicate of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Sigma_n\in PI$.

Since the work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicants of a formula is a lower bound on the number of terms that can be found in any $DNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, $
eg\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, so any $DNF$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. This is the clique detection function. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. However, it can be shown that $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicants, and hence not every $PI$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.

The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $PI$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

The transformation is in fact linear. We may recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee(\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewiring of nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and 1-edge. Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable; furthermore, all $\vee$-gates in the rewiring are deterministic, so we attain a $d$-$DNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNFdec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016,Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from dec-DNNF to nFBDD.

dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from dec-DNNF to NNF.

nOBDDnFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNFnOBDD in polynomial time, then dec-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-DNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

FBDDdec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDOBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDOBDD$_<$ being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

FBDDdec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If dec-DNNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDCNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where given each pair $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one of must be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise DNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Pi_n = \bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where after pairing $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one pair must have both be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise CNF.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.

separatingFunctions.name: Clique Detection Instances
separatingFunctions.description: Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$.
